data.title: Musings on East German pentaprism development
data.meta_description: Musings on East German pentaprism development Before WWII, Germany was widely considered THE maker of the "best" cameras. Those that couldn't afford to buy German cameras directly often made local copies such as the Soviet FED (1934) or various Japanese cameras. These were technically illegal, bu...
data.text:
Before WWII, Germany was widely considered THE maker of the "best" cameras. Those that couldn't afford to buy German cameras directly often made local copies such as the Soviet FED (1934) or various Japanese cameras. These were technically illegal, but ...

Leica copies - Wikipedia

The war made local copies for military use attractive, and the post-war appropriation of German patents for reparations made it legal. To the victor belong the spoils.

On the very cusp of the war, Zeiss Ikon had played around with a pentaprism eye-level mirror reflex camera- a mirror reflex Contax. There are "patent data" on this one but nothing but mockups were made, apparently. The mirror and prism are integral to the camera body, like the later-war and post-war Contax-S For "Spiegel 'mirror')

Ihagee was not idle either and produced some interchangeable prism attachments for their Exakta waist-level SLR.

Here's one with a viewfinder and light meter in addition to the eye-level prism (in pre-automatic aperture days the prism could be awfully dark).

Both the Contax and the Exakta were very expensive at first, so a more "volks" camera waist-level SLR called "Praktiflex" before the war and Praktica afterwards was made by KW. They, too, had a add-on prism available.

Looking through it had a certain "tunnel" effect, but it worked if the light was bright.

This was gradually improved and resulted in the first integrated prism for Praktica -though it stood high like a castle on the Rhein.

Praktica IV variants

As KW-Praktica developed their cameras it was widely copied even to the M42-mount., often with no acknowledgment at all, especially in Japan,

Jes' saying.
